												My Mum is in her 81'st year - bear with me - and she has had a go at one or two "experiences" in VR since I got my Vive last year. I thought she would love to try this. Within five minutes she was back at the place she grew up, giggling and squeeling with delight. Then she went up "Tandle Hill" and suddenly I noticed she wasn't laughing anymore.I asked her if she was ok, and I noticed she was quietly crying and shaking. "What's the MATTER"?, I asked."I haven't been here since I was a little girl; this is so wonderful - thank you so much, I never thought I would ever come here ever again".THAT, my friends, is worth the cost of the Vive itself.Pro's: Become Superman/Supergirl and go where you like; visit your own house; go to that place you always wanted to; sit on cliffs and scare yourself to death; "Leap" from tall buildings; Take off and go into space then land on the other side of the planet; go to that holiday place again (without the traffic jams); play a game of "can I find it again from space without getting lost on the way down"; save your own favourites and jump straight there next time. Change the time of day or night by dragging the Sun across the sky. All for FREE !!!!IN MY OPINION - the best and most enduring VR experience ever, and probably for a long time to come.Cons:Well, not really any, but I would like to see the following features added as this gem is polished:To be able to leave human scale on ALL THE TIME. I know it is great to feel like Gulliver, walking between the mountains or skyscrapers, but for immersion I'd like to be able to leave my eyes 70mm apart and view the Earth in normal scale (at least have the option).Ability to reverse the "BRAKE" option so that you are slow by default and you pull the trigger to accellerate; I, personally, want to take it all in, not rush off.I am not bothered about the comfort mode and prefer not to use it, but for those that get motion sickness, an option to change the size of the "tunnel" view to suit.I for one, don't mind that you can't text-search for places to "teleport" to; searching adds to the enjoyment, but I'll expect a lot of people would prefer the option.I know there's mirror mode, which you can modify to show just left/right eye as a circle on the screen, but for your friends to be able to view the experience full screen. I appreciate this could affect FPS etc, so just the option would be nice. Graphics settings, perhaps.Oh, I don't know, fly to and around the Moon next maybe?  ;-DThese are not complaints, just hopes for the future. This App is nothing short of incredible!

Just incredible. Lose yourself for hours.Neal Stephenson's novel Snow Crash is famous for offering a very forward-looking view at the Internet, online social interaction, and virtual reality (coining the term metaverse). One futuristic technology that it offhandedly predicted was a virtual globe that offered realtime satellite imagery of any place on Earth. I remember reading that particular bit and thinking how incredible it would be.We're not quite at that stage - well, not us consumers at least - but Google Earth comes very close indeed. An amazing app in and of itself, it becomes positively mind-blowing here with GEVR, applied to roomscale VR.There's nothing I can say that isn't better explained by the trailer video, so go ahead and watch that.Oh, but make sure you have really fast internet, and no data cap. GEVR is very very bandwidth hungry.Some things I would add: Photo mode: it already allows us to snap a photo when saving a place. Why not allow just snapping photos, and saving them in high-res? I was standing in the middle of the Himalayas, looking at row after row of snowy peaks, gobsmacked, and I so wanted to capture that view. Search: (EDIT: They added search!! April 2017) come on, you can't be a Google product, and Google Earth at that, and not have textual search. Google, you already made a nifty xylophone keyboard for Daydream, just use it here with a search interface. (EDIT: They added search!! April 2017) Street View: Again, it's already in the web app. It's probably not easy to implement - especially in terms of switching back and forth, and how to handle positional tracking and such - but it would be an amazing addition.Offline caching: (EDIT: April 2017 - with some ini editing, advanced caching is now supported!) 												I remember back when Google Earth first started up.  It was pretty cool back then, but there were a lot of gaps in the map...some of which I had actually been to visit, so it was kinda aggravating.  They added more and more to it, and then one day they started asking people to help by making 3D models of various buildings based on aerial photos.  It actually worked pretty well in some situations and the Earth slowly started being made 3D.I had no idea that was going to turn into this though.  In the areas where they've paid a lot of attention to the 3D models, it looks pretty damn good.  In those places where less attention was paid --well, it's kinda bad.  I shouldn't complain too much.  I could locate and somewhat recognize most of my old living quarters, though quite a few of them had trees obscuring everything. Anyway, this is Google Earth in VR... which is pretty awesome.  If you like Google Earth and like going to streetview from space and then walking around, you can't quite do that just yet.  I imagine they'll figure out how to make it work though.  Then I can do a virtual marathon, or see how long it would take me to walk in real time from New York City to L.A. (if you count walking back and forth around my living room to be valid).I really hope/wish that Google will take the time to get people to clean up some of the areas on the map.  I can accept that "B.F.E." isn't well maintained, but when a suburb of a major city has what looks like cobwebs hanging from the street signs, it's kinda lame.  Also, there's a few car shadows where they attempted to make a model of the car, but then it's like someone erased it, so there's a big grey hump on the road instead of a car.  They should just erase it better, or draw in a generic car over it so it looks better.Things I liked:  They've got a "comfort mode" which lowers the FOV until you're done moving so you don't get sick  Some of the scenery in the tours was fantastic  Saving your location is as easy as pressing a button  Navigation in general is pretty simple and you can fly over the city like superman (sorta)Things they need to work on:  clean up those ugly spots on the 3D model.  If you can't make it yourself, release the tools and let everyone do it as a steam workshop type thing.  Moving forward is fine, but turning is a drag (literally...hold a button and drag the map to turn)  They should make a flight mode where you turn as if you were in a small plane (or a jet or whatever).  Remote locations are still not filled in very well.  I did some time in one of those remote locations and even now it's mostly an aerial photo painted on the ground.  It's not really their fault but turning off the comfort mode did start to make me queasy, but the comfort mode turn reduces the FOV by way too much in my opinion.  I could probably go on with more pro AND con comments, but I know you're probably bored.  It's still awesome... grab it, download it, try it out...

												Google Earth VR is what you've been waiting for, secretly dreaming of - probably even before you got VR. The ability to travel anywhere in the world and actually immerse yourself in that place, beats looking at a flat screen any day. Google Earth has VAST data it can take advantage of, such as the many 3D buildings people ALL over the world have personally built with SketchUp or other applications and imported into Google Earth, we're talking about literally millions of contributions all over the world - finally we get to take full advantage of that.There are various ways to use Google Earth VR. You can either look at it from above, or take a flight across cities either on top of a 2D map or a 3D map if height-data is available. There are also areas, famous landmarks and cities that have been entirely re-built into 3D by dedicated users all over the world, you will be able to fly across (and even between) those buildings like a plane or a bird.But that's not all, you will also experience First Person View if you go into the settings (press the menu button on top of your controller) and go into the 3-dotted settings menu to your right, select the option to fly full body scale), also...if you don't feel motion sick - you can also turn off Comfort-Zone for a full view while you fly.Now - there's an extra thing to keep in mind while using this and that is your internet bandwidth. As of testing I was lucky enough to have a very fast broadband internet, mine happens to be 250 Mbit Down and 100 Mbit Up, the Upload speed is not that important to you here - so you want a fast download speed in order to fly fast and experience the graphics as detailed as possible, now this also depends on the speed of the Google servers and the entire routing between you, the internet and your computer to make it work seamlessly. Most of the time when you fly or walk around, you will notice that the roads have bumps in them, in fact you might even say that it looks like world war II was just recently here, but fret not - this is because Google uses the height data it has in its map-data, this is of course filled with errors here and there, so when you see a lot of bumps in the roads, it's either from people, cars or just errors and to you and me - this will look like graphical bumps in the road, something I'm sure they'll figure out an algorithm in the future to smooth out.In fact - you can still contribute - if you think your city or favorite area isn't represented here properly, you can still upload your 3D work, textures etc. to Google Maps - and it will probably be seen here in glorious VR 3D. And to think that this product is free - amazing.You will spend more than a couple of hours in here, I bet.

Posted: January 1
												Ever wanted to visit somewhere but without the jetlag? Maybe you want to visit somewhere you used to go. With a VR headset and Google Earth VR you can. You can select anywhere in the world manually, or use a list of presets. You can also favourite locations so you can get back to them quickly later.It isn't perfect: When you're at ground level, the area can take a long time to load (and I'm using a i7 4790k) and when you're up close, the detail is very low- buildings will typically spawn as basic polygons and slowly work into the correct shape. Even after it's finished loading, the detail is pretty low but it's enough for you to recognise significant locations. For example, I visited Japan a couple of months ago, so I thought I'd revisit the Tokyo Skytree in VR. I could make out the river nearby and some of the buildings I walked past on the way. It's a strange feeling seeing it all again in VR.Overall it's a pretty fun application to mess around with and it's free so you may as well. Over time maybe it'll become more detailed but it certainly serves its purpose. It would be nice if you could type in a place name though, rather than having to find it on the globe manually.

content:
Posted: January 7
												It doesn't even really make sense to review Google Earth VR because there is nothing else like it in the world today, a singular unique profound experience.  You can fly anywhere in the world in a heartbeat, and most cities (especially in US and Europe) have an unfathomable level of stereoscopic detail, to the point where you can read the signs of most large shops. You can see the world at a variety of scales, from standing on the street or on a beach or atop a building at human scale, to flying over an apartment complex or mall or airport, to flying over a city, to soaring above an entire region in orbit. It allows me to get a "feeling" for a place I've never been, so that when I go there, it already feels familiar. I stood by the poolside at my apartment complex. I went to a pier in Nice, France and adjusted the sun to see what it would like at sunrise. I went to an apartment I was thinking of renting in Daly City and studied the topography of the surrounding area to evaluate how foggy it might be. There is nothing like this, no end to the possibilities. And I'm even more excited for what the future may hold with richer data sets.That's not to say there isn't room for improvement. There's no way to navigate to a particular street address, or to see map labels while in "walking mode," or to superimpose useful data like directions between locations, traffic, population density, elevation. The level of detail is remarkable considering the scale, but at human scale still looks distorted and blurry compared to real life or Google Street View. Many developing or remote regions have only limited satellite data and appear mostly flat when you zoom in on them. It's a bit frustrating that I can't adjust the scale and my position independently - you can either be a human standing on the ground (or on a building) or you can be a giant standing on the ground. You can't be a human flying through the air. You also can't move straight up or down without awkwardly pointing your controller straight down below you, which is hard on my wrist. You can't rename saved locations to help you remember what they are. And although the streaming data solution is really effective, sometimes even on a very fast connection it can take a while to fully load the detail of a really detailed area. Sometimes I wish there were more extensive caching for areas that I visit frequently. And although I'm not prone to VR sickness, others who are may struggle with all the movement that this app requires (their comfort mode helps but will not work for everyone).In short: if you have a VR headset, you NEED to try this app. There's nothing like it on the planet.

												Google Earth is simply amazing for VR.I was hooked at the gorgeous introduction tour. It really showed me what VR is capable of. 												Alas. Earth was the last straw what brought me to VR. After settling down from traveling, I was looking forward to some virtual throw-back. I spend way too much time on mobile Google Maps' street view (blue sliding rail was a great addition). I was sorely disappointed with Earth VR. Most locations aren't yet built out in 3d, so they show as either a flat satellite image on the ground, or cities of grotesque polygonal blobs. Green blobs must be trees, white blobs buildings. It's that unrecognizable. Even the optimized locations like San Francisco and Paris seem barely there. Like you're looking at a model of a city on a table, objects made of clay to give you a gist, but lacking detail.I certainly realize the immense technological feat this app represents. The man hours and science pored into this incredible project, and I definitely don't want to poo-poo that. Earth has incredible potential, and I believe one day we'll be walking through virtual cities. But I think a down-vote is warranted simply because this is an app I couldn't spend more than 10m in before saying "eh, bummer." I've showed 2-3 people; they were ecstatic, went instantly to their hometowns or favorite cities, and dropped their arms in disappointment. They each tried some big city to see how the optimized locations look, and immediately asked to try a different VR experience. One day, Google - I believe in you.What's needed:- Street view. 												This is a must-have experience for any VR enthusiast. There's something special about being able to fly to somewhere you've been, or always wanted to be and feel like you're standing right there. Unlike using street view on a desktop, Google Earth VR allows you to explore the world through a more immersive perspective.I recently visited Arches National Park in Utah, so naturally I felt like checking it out in VR. Amazingly, when I turned the "Human Scale" mode on, the size of some of the landmarks felt identical to what I remembered only a few months ago. However, this mode is inactive by default so that you don't notice how blurry some of the textures are up close.You can save a seemingly unlimited number of locations to revisit, but unfortunately you cannot search for a specific landmark or address. They have some tours built in of famous cities, deserts, water features, etc. Overall, it's a great program to add to your "demo to your friends" list.Pros:+Sense of presence is stellar+Controls are easy to use+Navigation is simple+Good built-in tours of famous landmarks+Human scale mode is fairly accurate+It's freeCons:-No search feature-Long texture / geometry loads in some areas-If you live in a small town, you probably won't have any building models

It was really comfrortable, and some nice extra settings to tweak the experience.. thanks for those!The only problem is the lack of search feature. I found my house by starting at a landmark in the features menu that was on the opposite side of my country, and then spend about 15 minutes wrestling the flying features to narrow it down through thousands of kilometres of dirt and small towns I have never heard of, before hooking onto something I semi-recognised and then traced my way home from there. I spent the first day going to places I've lived and worked before. Conjuring memories, feelings for my recently departed mother (which the soundtrack definitely helped with. It is very soothing and peaceful) and this application pulled me back into the past. All the while showing me what has changed from what I remembered. While it isn't the easiest to find everything unless you can navigate without street names (I would think that would be something on the programming horizon) it's not that bad. There were a couple times when I would find the location on Google Maps on my monitor and just follow the topography VR until I found my destination.      The sense of scale is God Like. Feel like I am all powerful while in command of it (Would be cool in a Populace type game or strategy game). During my second day of scouting a new city to move to (San Antonio). I was looking at a neighborhood and remembered that it was a room scale experience. For a short time I started walking around thinking I could be a King Kong and smash everything below me. I must also say that I would love to see this much traffic in real life. There is none (basically, until you hit some traffic lights and then you can see ghost cars were they were captured but only fleetingly. I'll have to check New York City and see how many cars are present on the streets. See how bad traffic really is there and other places in the world.     All in all, I love this thing already. First off, it's free. Second, what you see is all real not make believe. In a way, it is learning also. Understanding your environment or places. Good way to scout around too. This is a great intelligence tool. Third thing is the controls in this application are very easy to master. One way I would get closest to the ground would be to point the hand control straight in the air and fly backwards until I can't go any closer to the ground. Since most of the time I am just sitting back, lounging with my feet kicked up for maximum comfortability. That brings in to the fourth reason. Four, you can chill and do this. You don't have to move things around if you have to prepare your play space. This can be a sitting, standing or moving around within this world.     Google Earth VR is so impressive. If you haven't tried it yet, there is nothing to lose and so much to gain. It has changed the way I will shop for places to rent also. Fly around the neighborhood, see if it looks good. How close it is to shops, grocery stores, neighbors and you can even see real life graffiti on buildings. So you can get a better idea of what it's like there. I am excited to see what improvements Google will make to this wonderful app. I got many ideas but I'm sure anyone that experiences this will also. Open your mind, and jump in. It'll be to a world you already know.

												Google earth VR is one of those applications that falls into the category of "things I will return to over and over" - for both useful familiarisation with a location to just aimless virtual meandering.  I would advise switching human scale on, so that when you "touch down" everything around you is to scale.  The moment you fly up the scale sneakily changes such that a city more resembles a scale model leaving you to stand head high with sky scrapers or fly up more and stride over districts, crouching and peering over buildings and features that capture your interest.GE comes with comfort mode on by default, which means that the centre is in focus as you move, but the outer areas are blur until you are at a standstill.  Personally I prefer to take that off, but I can see why some find it a bit much as you shoot off into the sky like some middle aged super hero.There are also some nice touches like being able to drag the sun across the sky to change the lighting, and a handy earth 'lollipop' to help you easily get roughly to where you want to go.Google earth VR is a happy marriage of a lot of historic work and technology that has been around for its own purposes,  and some added talent and serendipity to bring all of that to VR.  If you are (like my wife was) expecting photo realisim as you stand on some Tokyo street, then bear in mind the 3D assets are the same as you see in any other Google Earth incarnation -  as amazing as they are, they are the result of very ambitious arial scanning and as such at human scale the models have that melted cheese appearance.  It would be nice to see street view intergration as an optional layer, one where you stepped into and were contstrained to the Rails of the aquisition vehicle, until you opted back out to full 3D freedom.Another ommision is a way to search for places or landmarks.. Its a pain to have to leave VR to get your bearings and re-enter and find manually.I don't know how far the team intends on taking this project, but I hope they continue to push the great work forward, add a fun interface for viewing local photography or other layers; and maybe one day get to more frivolous features like believable ambient noises based on the locality, businesses , population and features such as forests, oceans and parks nearby -  I have to say, as silly as I look, I have even used GE VR to jog around Central Park...
